text: hi I'm Melissa Clark from the dining
section and I'm here to show you how to
make the crispiest the most succulent
the most delectable fried chicken ever
first thing you do is get your chicken
use whatever pieces you like I like
drumsticks thighs and wings if you like
breasts feel free to add them to the
bowl or just use a whole cut-up chicken
if you have time to plan this the day
before it's a really good idea to let
the chicken marinate overnight it adds a
lot of flavor I like to use buttermilk
buttermilk helps tenderize the pieces
all you want to do is just pour in
enough buttermilk to cover it and then
season it with whatever you feel like
seasoning it with I personally like
spicy chicken so I'm gonna add a little
bit of cayenne a lot of cayenne I'm
gonna add Tabasco but you can use any
spice you want sambal Olek is wonderful
sriracha any chili paste and then you've
got to use plenty of salt plenty of
pepper about at least a teaspoon per
pound of chicken pepper into your arm
gets tired just you know keep going
because we've added chili paste you
actually don't need a lot of black
pepper it just adds another layer of
complexity a couple of bay leaves some
garlic and some onion garlic does not
have to be finely chopped smash it throw
it in onion I'm just gonna Finley slice
then just mix everything together and if
it needs a little more buttermilk just
go ahead and pour some in you want the
buttermilk to just barely cover the
chicken pieces
so here's my chicken it's been
marinating for about two hours in the
fridge if you can do it overnight it
adds more flavor but even a couple of
hours will make a big difference but now
here's the thing about an hour or so
before you want to fry it take it out of
the fridge and let it come to room
temperature you don't want to fry cold
chicken because if you do it's gonna
cook unevenly and the outside will get
too brown before the inside cooks so
what do I have right here I've got just
regular old lunch bags doubled up two of
them so it's strong filled with flour
that's been seasoned aggressively with
salt and pepper you want to make sure
it's really well seasoned so that the
chicken gets well-seasoned what you want
to do is take your chicken and you
really want to just give it a little
shake so that the buttermilk falls off
put it in the bag close it up and get it
really well coated okay and as you can
see this is really thickly coated we're
gonna put it here and I'm just going to
repeat it with all the other pieces
until they're all nice and coated
you want to use a really heavy pot with
a lid this is a Dutch oven you can use a
skillet you can use your old cast-iron
frying pan as long as you have a lid
that fits on top of it now you want to
fill your pan with about a half an inch
of fat make sure to use clean fat
because if there are any rancid or
off-notes you're gonna taste it in the
chicken I can never make up my mind
about which is my favorite oil for
frying chicken current favorite right
now combination of duck fat and olive
oil they taste great together and the
duck fat helps raise a smoke point of
the olive oil which is important another
perennial favorite lard it's amazing
with fried chicken just gives it a
crackly crunchity you can also use
vegetable oil the thing about it is it's
bland so it's not actually adding
anything I'm using half duck fat and
half olive oil you only need about a
half an inch of fat in the pan because
you're not deep frying this chicken your
pan frying it so now I'm going to heat
up this oil until it reaches 350 on a
deep fat from on a deep fat fry so I'm
gonna heat the oil till it reads about
350 out of front let's just say
thermometer make sure that your
thermometer doesn't touch the bottom of
the pan otherwise you're gonna get a
higher reading when the oil reaches 350
you're gonna turn the heat down and add
your chicken make sure to use tongs cuz
it'll splatter and now I'm gonna cover
the pot so the chicken is frying make
sure to just keep an eye on the
thermometer you don't want the oil to go
above 350 or below 325 so just adjust
the heat as needed
I'm gonna cook the chicken covered for
five minutes then I'm gonna uncover it
flip the pieces and then cook it
uncovered for about 6 or so minutes and
then I'm gonna flip it one more time and
another five or six minutes until it's
done you'll know it's done when the
juices run clear when I take the chicken
out of the pot I'm going to put it on a
wire rack that way the grease can drip
off and it also won't steam by being in
direct contact with a plate
best-case scenario for piping-hot fried
chicken gather your hoards and have them
eat it immediately but if for some
reason you have a couple more batches
you want to fry you can hold this in a
200 degree oven just keep it on the rack
and then you get to eat the best part
